Follow Daily % Candles FX: The safe haven Japanese yen was the strongest major currency on the day, while the oil-sensitive fell the most, reaching a 1-month low against the US dollar. Meanwhile, continues to probe its lowest levels since the Great Financial Crisis. US data: The September ADP report printed at 135k vs. 140k eyed, though there were substantial negative revisions to the previous month’s report. Commodities: gained 1% while slumped -2% in its ninth consecutive loss as oil rose by more than expected. US Cash Indices % Change US indices closed sharply lower on the day, marking the worst 2-day start to a quarter since 2008 (see here and here for more) All sectors fell on the day, with REITs (Real Estate Select Sector SPDR (NYSE: )) falling the least and Energy stocks (XLE (NYSE: )) losing the most ground. Stocks on the move: Online brokers extended yesterday’s drop asTD Ameritrade Holding Corporation (NASDAQ: ) (TD, -3%) followed Charles Schwab (NYSE: , -3%) in cutting commissions for online trades to $0. All eyes now turn to E-TRADE Financial Corporation (NASDAQ: ) (ETFC, -4%) Ford Motor Company (NYSE: ) (F, -3%) and General Motors (NYSE: , -4%) both fell after reporting weak quarterly auto sales figures. Johnson & Johnson (NYSE: ) bucked the broader selling trend to gain 2% after the company cut a deal to avoid a trial over its involvement in the opioid epidemic. Economic Calendar Original Post
